The CARES Act is the largest stimulus package in American history, and there’s a real risk that money is going out the door with no strings attached because we lack aggressive, real-time oversight. The American people deserve to know their tax dollars are being spent effectively.

The CARES Act Congressional Oversight Commission was created *eight months ago* to monitor bailout money going to large corporations, and it still lacks a Chair. What’s more, the Trump Administration refuses to release comprehensive data on PPP loan recipients.
It’s that simple. http://pbs.twimg.com/tweet_video_thumb/EnXaoRXXIAIyA6r.jpg https://video.twimg.com/tweet_video/EnXaoRXXIAIyA6r.mp4

@SymetraTourCBO We just shouldn't assume those market inefficiencies don't exist, and should be ever-vigilant to ensure that the reasons the distortions were first put in place are still necessary, lobbyists-insistence to that point notwithstanding.

@SymetraTourCBO That's OK.  There is nothing wrong with wanting to use markets AND not wanting the power to the refrigerator keeping grandma's medicine chilled to be cut off just because she can't afford to pay a surging spot price for power.

@SymetraTourCBO And to be clear, I'm not sure any purely-market driven economy has built high capex, low margin commodity industries, nor ensured equitable access for critical things like energy, water, etc.

@SymetraTourCBO Well... subject to appropriately pricing externalities and without making any call for unilateral disarmament, maybe.  My point is simply that we should never talk about a sector with as many distortions as the energy sector in pure-market principles.

15/ And as you succeed... as you remove those market distortions so that your inherently economically-superior products can thrive... don't lose sight of how you got there.  Competition is hard.  I get it.  It is our collective obligation to fight for it. /fin

14/ Meanwhile, to my friends in the clean energy industry, a request: get organized.  Push for barrier / subsidy removal as hard or harder than you push for more incentives.  Otherwise we're just putting ever bigger engines in a car that still has the emergency brake on.
13/ On my end, we will continue to push for pro-market policies and will call out those who use the language of markets to support anti-market, crony-capitalism.

12/ (As an aside on that last one, when China directs their banks to invest in low-return belt & road initiatives we rightly bash it as anti-market.  This is no different, and folks at the @USOCC deserve the same criticism.)

11/ And why today the @USOCC is seeking to compel banks to invest in the fossil sector, regardless of market fundamentals.  https://twitter.com/vtg2/status/1329881714974453762?s=20 QT @vtg2 The @USOCC today proposed cracking down on big banks that deny loans & other services to entire industries like energy companies or private prisons. Brooks, who’s in the process of being formally nominated for comptroller, is already raking in GOP praise.
https://occ.gov/news-issuances/news-releases/2020/nr-occ-2020-156.html

10/ And why when the COVID-driven downturn came last spring, one of the first things the Trump administration did was inject tax payer $ to try and prop up the oil industry.  https://www.energy.gov/articles/department-energy-executes-direction-president-trump-announces-solicitation-purchase-crude

9/ That is why the US subsidizes the fossil fuel sector to the tune of $650 billion / year.  https://www.imf.org/en/Publications/WP/Issues/2019/05/02/Global-Fossil-Fuel-Subsidies-Remain-Large-An-Update-Based-on-Country-Level-Estimates-46509

8/ But as Smith understood, the opportunity that exists to create more market-friendly conditions is precisely what makes it so hard.  We pay lip service to competitive markets, but the incentives of "civil government" as constituted in the US don't push that way.
7/ And for what it's worth, Adam Smith made this point more pithily 200+ years ago: http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EnWgUjlXUAc9OQW.png

6/ It's why I said that the top priority of the Biden administration should be eliminating fossil fuel subsidies.  https://twitter.com/RepCasten/status/1326943247596462088?s=20 QT @RepCasten As wildfires rage and hurricanes batter our coastlines, coal plants continue to be subsidized by Medicaid which picks up the tab for downwind pollution-induced asthma and premature fatalities. 

It’s time we #EndFossilFuelSubsidies once and for all (via @climate). http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Emo_1I5XEAI8vWc.jpg

5/ And furthermore, even those who would benefit from the removal of those distortions rarely make that ask; they ask for incentives to counter the headwind rather than ask us to get rid of the conditions WE CREATED that made their progress so hard.

4/ This holds us back, but is also an enormous opportunity.  The incentives that created all those anti-market policies also mean that we have enormous opportunities to make our markets more efficient by removing existing, regulated distortions.

3/ But no one comes to DC and says "Hey, can you make the world safer for my competitors?"  Which is fine... but for the fact that policies that are expressly designed to be pro-business are often pitched in pro-market language.  Those terms are not always (rarely?) synonymous.

2/ By economic efficiency, I mean the stuff you learned in the 1st chapter of freshman econ which was stipulated to be true for the math in the rest of the book to hold up. No barriers to entry / exit.  Transparency of information.  etc.
1/ First, an observation that is too often over-looked.  NO ONE comes to Washington to advocate for economic efficiency.  That is a problem, and a massive opportunity.
